DOCNAME: SHIMIDZU AND BERLLAQUE v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
JUDGES: Giovanni Bonello;Lech Garlicki;Ledi Bianku;Nebojša Vučinić;Nicolas Bratza;Päivi Hirvelä
TEXT: The applicants , Mr PERSON and Mr PERSON , are NORP nationals who were born in DATE and DATE respectively . They live in GPE . Mr Shimidzu was represented before the ORG by PERSON D. ORG , a barrister practising in GPE ; PERSON by PERSON PERSON , a barrister also practising in GPE . They were each assisted by ORG and Mr C. Nicholls GPE , counsel .
ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent , PERSON of ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

On CARDINAL–CARDINAL DATE , the first applicant , PERSON , was tried before a judge and jury in ORG on charges of assault occasioning bodily harm , obstructing a police officer and resisting a police officer in the execution of his duty . He was acquitted by the jury after a submission of no case to answer was rejected by the trial judge . When Mr ORG ’s counsel made application for costs after the trial , the Chief Justice said :
“ But , PERSON , you know that you ca n’t get costs . I would grant them , if I could , you know that the law is against you . ”
When counsel persisted the Chief Justice said :

“ You keep trying , PERSON , I understand why you keep trying , but in my opinion it is an unjust system , which says , you can award costs against the defendant on conviction , you can not award costs in ORG on acquittal . It is not a just system , but it ’s not something that I can get round , however much I would enjoy trying to weave it . I just can not , and it is a matter for the ORG , but it is a matter perhaps that the ORG ought to be invited to give their attention to . ”

On DATE , the second applicant , PERSON , was tried before the same court on charges of rape . At the conclusion of the prosecution case , the trial judge upheld a defence submission of no case to answer and , on his direction , the jury acquitted the second applicant .
Mr ORG made a motion to challenge the refusal to award costs . This was referred by ORG to ORG of Gibraltar on DATE .

PERSON was given leave to intervene in the proceedings before ORG in Mr Shimidzu ’s case . Before ORG , the applicants argued , inter alia , that the relevant provision of NORP criminal law , section CARDINAL of the Criminal Procedure Ordinance , violated LAW . They relied on sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the LAW . In respect of section CARDINAL , they argued that LAW violated their right to a fair hearing and was a violation of the presumption of innocence . It appears that it was accepted before ORG that while section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) allowed ORG to order the prosecution to pay costs to an acquitted defendant , all defendants before ORG would be unable to fulfil the conditions laid down in CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) since in order for a person to be committed for trial they would have to be detained in custody or bound by recognizance ( see section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) ( a ) below ) . ORG unanimously rejected the applicant ’s submissions in respect of the presumption of innocence and the prohibition on discrimination contained in section CARDINAL . By a majority , it found that section CARDINAL violated the right to a fair hearing contained in section CARDINAL .

The Attorney - General for ORG appealed to ORG of ORG . On DATE , ORG allowed the appeal , holding that section CARDINAL , while unattractive and lacking even - handedness , did not violate the LAW . This unattractiveness was relieved by the fact that the subsection ( CARDINAL ) of the section , allowing the prosecution to claim costs from a convicted defendant , was a dead letter . ORG , relying on this ORG ’s rulings in PERSON and PERSON v. the GPE , judgment of DATE , Series A no . CARDINAL , § § DATE and PERSON v. GPE , judgment of CARDINAL DATE , Series A no . CARDINAL , § CARDINAL , found that LAW did not require a discretion to award costs to an acquitted defendant . While an even - handed discretionary power to order reimbursement of costs incurred by a successful prosecutor or a successful defendant would be desirable , it was not correct to find , as ORG had , that such a power was universal among LOC countries . The principle of equality of arms sought to ensure that a defendant did not suffer an unfair procedural disadvantage but did not require that the situations of the prosecutor and defendant should be assimilated and neither applicant had been able to show any procedural disadvantage in the conduct of the trial from the inability to recover his costs . In respect of the presumption of innocence ( and referring to this ORG ’s findings in PERSON , cited above ; PERSON v. the GPE , judgment of DATE , Reports of Judgments and Decisions CARDINAL ; and PERSON v. GPE , judgment of DATE , Series A no . CARDINAL ) , ORG found that where the domestic court had a discretion to order costs against a prosecutor in favour of an acquitted defendant , the court should not refuse to make such an order in terms which threw doubt on the presumption of innocence . However , where domestic law granted no discretion and did not permit the making of an order , the failure to make such an order could not be rationally understood as throwing doubt on the defendant ’s innocence .
Section CARDINAL of LAW DATE ( now superseded by LAW ) , in so far as it is relevant , provided as follows :

“ It is hereby recognised and declared that in GPE there have existed and shall continue to exist without discrimination by reason of race , place of origin , political opinions , colour , creed or sex , but subject to respect for the rights and freedoms of others and for the public interest , each and all of the following human rights and fundamental freedoms , namely―
( a ) the right of the individual to life , liberty , security of the person and the protection of the law ; ...

... and the provisions of this LAW shall have effect for the purpose of affording protection to the said rights and freedoms subject to such limitations of that protection as are contained in those provisions , being limitations designed to ensure that the enjoyment of the said rights and freedoms by any individual does not prejudice the rights and freedoms of others or the public interest . ”
Section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) , insofar as they are relevant , provided as follows :
“ “ Provisions to secure protection of law

CARDINAL.(CARDINAL ) If any person is charged with a criminal offence , then , unless the charge is withdrawn , the case shall be afforded a fair hearing within a reasonable time by an independent and impartial court established by law .
( CARDINAL ) Every person who is charged with a criminal offence ―
( a ) shall be presumed to be innocent until he is proved or has pleaded guilty ;
( c ) shall be given adequate time and facilities for the preparation of his defence ;

( d ) shall be permitted to defend himself in person or , at his own expense , by a legal representative of his own choice or , where so prescribed , by a legal representative provided at the public expense ... ”
Sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL also provided protection against deprivation of property .
Part ORG of the Ordinance governs costs and other ancillary orders in criminal cases .
Section CARDINAL , governing the award of costs by ORG , so far as it is relevant , provides :
“ ( CARDINAL ) On the summary trial of an information the GPE court shall have power to make such order as to costs ―
( a ) on conviction , to be paid by the defendant to the prosecutor ; and
( b ) on dismissal of the information , to be paid by the prosecutor to the defendant , as it thinks just and reasonable :
Provided that ―

( i ) where under the conviction the court orders payment of any sum as a fine , penalty , forfeiture or compensation , and the sum so ordered to be paid does not exceed £ CARDINAL , the court shall not order the defendant to pay any costs under this subsection unless in any particular case it thinks fit to do so ;

( ii ) and where the defendant is a child or young person , the amount of the costs ordered to be paid by the defendant himself under this subsection shall not exceed the amount of any fine ordered to be so paid .
( CARDINAL ) The court shall specify in the conviction , or , as the case may be , the order of dismissal , the amount of any costs that it orders to be paid under subsection ( CARDINAL ) .

( CARDINAL ) Where examining justices determine not to commit the accused for trial on the ground that the evidence is not sufficient to put him upon his trial , and are of opinion that the charge was not made in good faith , they may order the prosecutor to pay the whole or any part of the costs incurred in or about the defence . ”
At the relevant time , section CARDINAL , governing the award of costs by ORG , provided :

“ ( CARDINAL ) ORG may , if it thinks fit , order any person convicted before it to pay the whole or any part of the costs incurred in or about the prosecution and conviction , including any proceedings before the examining justices .
( CARDINAL ) Where any person is acquitted on indictment , then , if ―
( a ) he has not been committed to or detained in custody or bound by recognizance to answer the indictment ; or
( b ) the indictment is for an offence under LAW ;
( c ) the indictment is by a private prosecutor for the publication of a defamatory libel or for any corrupt practice within the meaning of ORG ,
ORG may order the prosecutor to pay the whole or any part of the costs incurred in or about the defence , including any proceedings before the examining justices .
( CARDINAL ) Costs payable under this section shall be taxed by the Registrar . ”
Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) was repealed by ORG with effect from DATE .
